roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Petitioner versus Frank J. Pate, Warden.
Mr. Lassers, you may continue your argument.
Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.
At the habeas corpus hearing before Judge Perry, the -- we produced evidence regarding a pair of jockey shorts.

These shorts were originally introduced with the 1956 trial and at that time it was evidence from Mr. Litterly that I mentioned yesterday that these shorts have Type A blood on them and there was some out there evidence which we question that that the little girl who was murdered also had Type A blood and these shorts according to the prosecution theory had been worn by the petitioner and had been abandoned by him in his flight.
We pre --

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: May I ask?
How did the testimony of the little girl who had Type A blood get into the case?
The mother was -- testified to that effect.
It was a hearsay testimony as far as she was concerned but it got into the record.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: You say, she did not testify --
She did.
The mother of the little girl testified, Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- in shape that --
In shape, yes, correct.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Based upon what did she say?
She didn't say.
It was fudge.
It appeared as though she was based at a school record tied in with the child's weight.
But she made the statement that she had a Type A blood and that's all the evidence there was at the trial as to the little girl's blood type.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Is there any question about the accuracy of the statement?
Well, we -- we think it was hearsay evidence, Mr. Justice Black.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I understand that it was hearsay --
Yes.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- but it was in without objection.
Well --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Is there any question about the accuracy?
We have no way of knowing positively because the child is dead.
So we can't verify one way or the other.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Have you made any efforts to find out?
We have made efforts inconclusive.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Asked a doctor?
I'm sorry.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Did you ask a doctor?
Yes, we made various inquiries at the hospital and so forth.
They turned up some slips which showed Type A blood but the exact timing and dates and it was very confused.
We couldn't establish it either way.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: So did they had the Type A blood but it didn't show the time that she had it, is that it?
I don't remember the details whether the slip was undated or what the problem was but I remember that we couldn't establish it either way.
Now --

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I suppose if she had the type of blood any time she would always have it.
That is -- it's my understanding that that is correct, Mr. Chief Justice.

Now, at the District Court hearing, for the first time, Judge Perry permitted us to have a scientific examination made of the shorts and at that time, we produced evidence showing that the shorts were saturated not with blood but they were saturated with paint.
Now, we've actually brought up the shorts up here, they look terrible Your Honors and they -- all what you see here is paint and not blood.
Now --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, how do you tell by looking at it that's paint and not blood?
We cannot Your Honor, Mr. Justice Black, no.
It took us --
Was there any blood?
What?
Was there any blood in the shorts?
That is a disputed fact.
Now, our chemist testified that he could find no evidence of blood.
He made this test in December of '63.
Now, there was testimony back in '56 by the state witness Litterly that he found blood on the shorts.
But our man couldn't find any in '63.
Now --

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Did they find any in '63?
The state?

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: The state, yes.
The state didn't make any new test in '63 one way or the other.
Now --

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: How obvious is that -- is the red part of it that you attribute to paint than they attribute to blood on the shorts?
I didn't hear your question.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: How obvious is the paint on the shorts that --

Well, this was always referred to at the 1956 trial as the blood stained shorts even petitioner so referred to it and Litterly, in the '56 testimony said, he talked about -- he said that the red -- the staining material on the shorts were -- was blood.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, as repulsive as it maybe, would you open it up so I can see it?
Certainly.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Now, is there any question about it that what everything we can see there is paint.
I don't think there is any question, Mr. Chief Justice.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: So the state contends that anything that can be seen on there now is blood.
They have not challenged that.

All that they can claim was that there was -- that their testimony -- that their expert in '56, said that there was blood but I think it is undisputed now that everything that Your Honors see is paint.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes, but didn't the counsel for the petitioner at the original trial in 1956 see those shorts?
Yes he did, Mr. Justice Fortas.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And what did he do after he saw them?
Well --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Did he have an analysis made of them?
Did he ask --?
He moved the Court to have a scientific examination made of the shorts and it was denied.
So he couldn't present --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: What do you mean he moved the Court to have a scientific examination made?
Did he move --
He presented a motion.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Did he move -- did he move that he'd be allowed to have an expert examine the shorts?
That is correct.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And that was denied?
It was denied.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Now, had he had an opportunity and have such scientific examination made prior to trial?
He moved it in May that it was an examination to examine all the physical evidence, to have a scientific examination made.
It was made in May and the trial was held in September.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: So that -- and that was denied in May.
It was denied.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: So that your point about the subsequent District Court hearing in 1961 or whenever it was.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Is merely that it's a dramatic demonstration of the fact that this was a prejudicial error.
That is correct, Your Honor.
Yes.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Was there motion made directly and specifically to the judge, stating that this was not blood but was paint?
No.
No, Mr. Justice Black, it was not.
There was no way to tell as I understand it by looking at this, what this stating material is.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But what do you mean when you say that he made a motion?
He made a motion to have a scientific examination made of all of the physical evidence in the case.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: That they have to have a scientific investigation there.
What kind of scientific --
It was not specified.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- of all the evidence in the case.
It was -- of all the physical evidence.
It was not specified and there was a --
Is there any question amongst as to where these pants were in '56 to '63?
They were in the hands of the prosecution up to the time of the trial and then they were in the -- I believe in the possession of the trial court.
I'm not certain of that.

And then they were transmitted to the Supreme Court of Illinois and we got them into the hands of the District Court from the Supreme Court of Illinois and then they went to the Court of Appeals and then they came to this Court.
Now, the -- there are two other errors Your Honors that we feel are critical here.

One relates to the state's star witness, Betty Baldwin who is now Betty Baldwin-Curry who testified that on the night of the murder that this -- that the petitioner admitted the crime to her in the course of a taxi ride, he was a taxi driver and in 1963, before Judge Perry, she recanted her testimony and denied that she had ever -- that he had ever made such a statement to her.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Did his confession make any reference to having admitted the crime to her?
I don't -- no, I don't believe it did.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I thought it had.
It did?
Mr. Rosenfield says that it does make such a reference.
Now, at the '63 trial, again by discovery, we learned for the first time of a statement in the prosecution files given by this woman very shortly after the crime.
At the '56 trial, she was asked how long she had known the petitioner and her answer was two years.
And at the 19 -- and the statement that she gave to the prosecution right after the crime was that she had known him for five weeks.
Now, that was first learned by us in 1963.
Then there was a whole long list of other facts known to the prosecution prior to the ‘56 trial which cast serious doubt on the reliability and trustworthiness of this witness.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: What was the time relevance here or importance of the length of time she had known him?

Because if she had known him for two years, Mr. Justice Black then if she conveyed the impression -- conveyed the impression to the jury that it was the -- that there was the kind of relationship between them that if he had committed a crime that he would admit it to her whereas if it was only five weeks, it would be less likely that he would make such an admission to somebody that he had just knew very briefly.
Now, the -- my time has expired, Your Honors and I want to save some time for rebuttal.

We're not going to -- because I have mentioned that I don't want the Court of Appeals that we think that they're unimportant but there were serious questions with regard to being cut off in the examination of a key defense witness Mrs. Alice Baxter who is the landlady.
And the landlady came up to the 1963 trial and said that he was in his room in her house at the time that the crime took place.
In '56, before the trial, the defense counsel tried to interview this witness.

She spoke to him once or twice and then the -- then she called the prosecution and the prosecution told her that she has a constitutional right not to talk to the defense counsel and then she refused to talk to him any further.
So she was listed as a prosecution witness in 1956.
She was not called by the defense in '63, as I said, she came forward and she said that he was in her house at the time of crime.
Alright, are you or somebody on your side going to deal with the claim that the -- confession itself is coerced?

I intended to deal with that Your Honor but my time is going down except for the fact that there was a lie about the hair plus the fact that the prosecution told -- he asked to see his parents and the police told him, “You can't see your parents.
Your parents don't want to have anything more to do with you.”
And all the time the parents were out trying to find out where he was in lining up an attorney.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I understand -- I understand, Mr. Lassers that the defense tried to call this lady, Mrs. Baxter at the trial, is that correct?
That is correct.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And they tried to -- because they couldn't talk to her after the prosecution had told her that she had a constitutional right not to talk to him.
They asked the Court to let them examine her as a court witness.
That is right, Mr. Chief Justice.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: The prosecution said that they would only do that if the defense admitted her unreliability and the Court on that objection refuse let her be examined as a court witness.
Is that the fact?
That is the fact, Your Honor and it is so stated in the record and in fact Mr. Malmgren, the defense counsel said I will not state that she is unreliable.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: What was the statement based upon that she was unreliable.
Is there anything to indicate that?
Oh!
No, no.
The defense counsel would refuse to say that she was unreliable.
His point was that he didn't know what her testimony was going to be and he couldn't risk being bound by her testimony.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes, yes, I understand that but I mean, has anything developed since to indicate that Mrs. Baxter was not reliable?
No.
I -- no.
I would say, no.

But there was some suggestion in the record that say that they put in an affidavit that she had given some contrary testimony -- made a contrary statement to a prosecution with -- that was introduced in '63.
But when she -- but nobody has really challenged her for it.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: What is the importance?
Because it --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: What is the importance that you attribute to the statement that a witness didn't have to talk to somebody on the outside if he didn't want to?
Yes, Mr. Justice Black because it cut the defense off not only from this live witness.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But he did cut the defense?
Right.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Do you claim that a person who doesn't have a right to refuse to talk to somebody and tell him about the facts of the case before they put him on the stand?
Our point is Your Honor that it was wrong for the prosecution to chill the defense in this avenue of exploration.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: If they were asked a question, what is wrong with saying if you don't think you have to just talk to him unless you want to?
Because in -- Your Honor, we feel that in a murder trial, particularly, that the defense is seriously handicapped if the prosecution compel --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Admitting that --
Right.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: What I'm asking is, do you claim that because of anytime of trial, a person has got to talk to the lawyers or defendant in the case if he doesn't want to?
No Your Honor, no.
If this had been her --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: That's why I can't understand the great emphasis because on that.
No, only if she had said voluntarily of her own will, “I don't want to talk to you” then perfectly alright.
But I think it was wrong for the prosecution to say to her to --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Are you saying that the prosecution voluntarily went out of their way to tell a witness that they didn't have to talk -- I don't understand.
That might have been thought of?
She called -- I believe that the record shows that she called the prosecuting attorney and then the prosecuting attorney --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And asked him.
And asked him.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: If she had to testify.
Not to testify but to talk --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: That she had to talk to him.
And he said --
Correct.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- she didn't have to.
She's -- he said --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Is that the whole circumstance?
He said that to her and to some certain other witnesses and the prosecutor so testified in '63.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, I understand that but I think it's perfect and normal thing, it seems to me, if one person calls of another and asking the lawyer, “Do I have to talk on the outside?”
And said “No.”
I don't quite understand the great emphasis you put on there.
It may have it but I don't yet quite get it.
Well, the point is that if he had been allowed to complete that inquiry that then she would have been available as a witness.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: If who had been allowed can be?
If the defense counsel had been allowed to --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Then if the defense counsel --
Yes.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- gotten this witness to talk, he could have found out more than he did.
Yes.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But why do you attribute some wrongdoings of the prosecuting attorney and answer the question and saying you don't have to testify?
Well, we feel that his advice was wrong that she had a constitutional right and so forth.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Oh!
You think that she did not have a right to refrain from talking on the outside of the Court?
If it was up to her, she could make her own decision but the prosecution should --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: What you said so far, you've made it after her, but she called the prosecutor, you've said it?
Yes.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And ask if she had to talk to this man and he said no.
What's wrong with that?
Well, I think you should have said to her in fairness to the defense that you go ahead -- he asked to prepare his case.
I think that would've been the part where it is.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: We don't claim legal error for a prosecuting attorney to make that answer, do you?
We do Your Honor.
Well, we might mention also that the Gregory case which decided recently by the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, somewhat similar circumstances.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But would she have to testify?
She testified in 1963.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But she didn't testify in the trial?
No Mr. Justice White, she did not.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: You contend that the state had information about what Mrs. Baxter might testify to and didn't reveal it to the prosecution?
We don't know what they --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Did you ever asked in the '63 hearing?
Didn't you -- did you go into that matter whether these facts which Mrs. Baxter -- would you know Mrs. Baxter would testify to it?
Did you ask the prosecution whether they lose out in '56?
They put in their own evidence on that point.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: On what point?

They put in evidence saying that some official had interviewed her and she had told them -- given them a different story but she testified in '63, she and her husband and the two grandchildren, placing him in the house at the time of the crime.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well so, she's given -- she essentially gave two different stories there.
One in the prosecution and one in the --
We don't say that Mr. Justice White because that was just a hearsay --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, why --
They just put it in an affidavit.
They didn't put the man on the stand.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, yes, the prosecution -- that's the prosecution's claim, isn't it?
That's their claim, yes.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And it's your claim that she has testified something else.
Yes.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Does the affidavit of the prosecution as to what she said fit with the theory of their case as it was tried?
I think it does.
Thank you, Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. Rosenfield.
Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.
I appear here on behalf of two amici, the American Civil Liberties Union, Illinois Division and the Chicago Radio Station, WAIT.
The amici are here because they believe of what is said to be a ghost which stalks the legal system.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Ghost of what?
What is said to be a ghost, which stalks the legal system, the possibility of sentencing an innocent man to death has come to life in this case.
We believe it has come to life in this case.
We argue that police and prosecutor indecency measured by due process standards, concealed the innocence of this accused, petitioner here.
The controlling case is Brady against Maryland.

And the crucial point is the suppression of an official report of the State Bureau of Criminal Identification and Investigation to the effect that here, found in the vagina of a victim was not that of the accused.
The crucial point is that this report was suppressed for eight years.
It was known to the prosecution.
It was sent to the prosecution.
The prosecutors admitted the habeas corpus hearing that they knew about it.
The report was never disclosed.
It was brought to life for the first time in the habeas corpus proceeding in the federal court.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Was there any evidence adduced by the prosecution at the trial to the effect that this hair was from the body of the defendant?
Hairs were not admitted at the trial at all.
Nothing --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: There is no evidence at all --
No evidence at the trial at all on hairs.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And so this man --
All we know.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: This man was convicted without any evidence at all --
About the hair.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: - one way or the other --
One way or the other --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- that the hair is from his body?
Crucial point.
The point I'm making is that the official report of the state -- Criminal Investigation Department was exonerated, totally exonerated.
It's impossible for the mind to conceive of any explanation for that hair of being in the vagina of the victim, other than it was a hair of the attacker.
And this, we are told by recognized police manuals, all of the police manuals, happens frequently in rape and sex cases.
In fact, the cardinal principle in the investigation of such cases according to the police manuals is to search for hairs.
That was done.
Now, the fact that it was in the vagina, stands admitted on this record by the Attorney General of Illinois.
No question has been raised about that, no one has ever raised that question.
And the critical point is the suppression of the report which is not an inference, that's null and that's admitted.
The report was never disclosed.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Is there any question as to whether this was a pubic hair or not?
We know for comparative purposes, Mr. Chief Justice that a pubic hair was taken from the accused.
The nature of the hair in the child's vagina is not exactly known.

Inference, I would think that it is pubic because the hair, the forensic medicine books tell us that hairs have different characteristics from the different parts of the body but I can't say that there's anything in the record.
All we know that it was a hair, the probability is that it was a pubic hair in the vagina of an eight-year-old child.
Now the --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Your -- your position is a little different in that, isn't it?
That is to say that there was a written report by --
There was a written report.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- by a state scientist --
Which came from the Department of Criminal Investigation.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And that was in the possession of the prosecution at the time, before the trial and at the time of trial, is that right?
Yes Mr. Justice Fortas, that's the point I was trying to make.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And that said that there was a plastic container which contained two pubic hairs, one from the girl and the other that was found.
No sir.
It contained a vaginal smear, a vaginal -- a vaginal smear from the child.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes.
The vaginal smear was examined by the state department and the hair was discovered by the state department.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes.
When the accused was taken into custody, one of the -- virtually, the first act the police did was to take a pubic hair from him --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I see.
-- for comparative purposes.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And the -- and the report --
At that point, they recognized with the size of significance of the hair in the vial.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And those two hairs were --
Were compared --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- by the state.
-- and found to be a mismatch.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And the state -- the state scientist who examined this so reported.
So reported.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And that his written report so stated that it was in the possession of the prosecution before trial and at the time of trial, is that right?
It was sent to the prosecution.
It was in the hands of the prosecution, the facts that were known to the prosecution and that is what I meant to be saying is the report that was suppressed.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Now, did the -- yes, I see.
The hair that was in this plastic container or rather in the vaginal smear, was that identified as a pubic hair in the written report?
That was -- the hair in the container was not identified in the report as a pubic hair.

In answer to Mr. Chief Justice Warren a moment ago, I said that I thought the probability was high that it was a pubic hair because pubic hairs are known to have different characteristics from hairs of -- from other parts of the body.
However, the report does not say that.
It does state that the hair of the accused which was compared was a pubic hair and therefore it was found to be a mismatch.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And your point, very simply stated is that whatever the inference may or may not be that this is relevant and of great importance as part of the trial and that the prosecution had a duty to advice a defense in its existence.
That sir is exactly my point.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Was the confession that the -- that was introduced at the trial contested of being having been coerced?
It was vigorously contested as having been coerced.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Did the --
It obviously does not meet Miranda standards but I'm not arguing that point.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes.
Did the -- did the defendant testify on that proceeding?

The defendant did testify both in chambers, outside the presence of the jury and before the jury.The defendant denied -- at that point, he has denied consistently from that moment that he had ever confessed.

He is claiming that the paper he signed, he didn't know what the paper was that it was a -- he was coaxed into signing this paper in order to avoid going to the electric chair after 52 hours of interrogation.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Does he mean --
I don't mean to imply that all 52 hours involved interrogation after 52 hours of detention.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Did he testify at that time that the police told him they had found the hair that matched with his?
He testified at that time and the episode is somewhat garbled.
No one paid much attention to it because it was never known until eight years later in a habeas corpus proceeding that the state report existed, exonerating report existed.
At that time, he testified that somewhere during the 52 hours of detention, he was somehow told that hair has incriminated him.
That's all it appears that that hair is somehow incriminated him.
It does not appear that it was told that a hair was in the child's vagina.
He was simply told that the hair has incriminated him.
He asked, he jumped to the microscope himself and said let me look and “them hairs don't match”.
This is his testimony at the trial in the trial record and it's all we know about the hair episode.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Now, when that was raised by the defendant, did the prosecution respond to it in anyway?
It did not respond to it.
It did not respond to it any way.
It was not counted.

When -- I might say this Mr. Chief Justice, when the accused counsel were permitted to look at the state's evidence, there were hair, hairs were among the evidence exhibited to them but no -- not the report just for hairs as evidence that the state would rely upon, so as counsel would be jumped or they form the opinion if the hairs were somehow favorable to the state.
Hairs were among the evidence exhibited --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: When was it exhibited?
Some point before the -- at some point before the trial.
Not the report.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes, but at that point, could the -- could the matter of the examination had been pursued which had been previously turned down.
You told to Mr. Justice Fortas that there had been a motion and a denial in May.
And when it was the -- when the physical evidence was finally exhibited to the defense, at that point, did the defense had an opportunity to pursue the matter of an examination?
They did not have an opportunity.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Did they attempt to?
They asked.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: At that time also?
At that -- I don't -- all that appears in the record is that they ask several times.
How many times?
We don't know.
The prosecutor testified for habeas corpus proceeding that they asked continuously.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Asked what?
Asked for permission to examine the physical evidence, the point that Mr. Lassers --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I thought you said they had it and was presented?
They were permitted to look at it.
Look -- simply to look at it.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But couldn't they protect it?
That I don't know.
They were just permitted to look at it.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: It was turned over to them to look at.
Or --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Or was it?
I don't know.
The record is silent at it.
So I simply don't know.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: So we don't know whether it was turned over to them to look at it?
Or it was just -- or it was just open to their examination and -- at some place or some point.
Mr. Lassers tells me, in the presence of the sheriff, they were permitted to see --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But it was not -- none of these things was surrendered to them?
None of these things were surrendered to them.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Now, may I ask --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, I don't suppose it should have been surrendered to them really.
That's -- if this --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I suppose the state would want to keep it if it was evidence.
I beg your pardon, Mr. Justice Black.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I suppose the state would want to keep it if it was evidence.
Yes, so the District Court but all things there were made available for scientific -- for examination by the --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes, I thought (Voice Overlap).
By the Federal District Court.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But what -- I'm not sure yet about this testimony in the accused himself about the hairs and he's looking into the microscope and so forth that this -- was that testimony the testimony that he gave at the trial in connection with the challenge to the admissibility of the confession?
It was sir.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And was that out of the presence of the jury?
It was out of the presence of the jury.
It was at the hearing on the admissibility of the confession in which he was recounting chronologically what happened to him during the 52-hour incommunicado detention period.
Now, the treatment of this point --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Does the record show whether the hairs themselves were in the Courtroom on the occasion of that testimony?
It does not show.
The report certainly was not, the exonerating report.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And that I gather when -- after the confession was admitted, the state as part of its case, I think you've already told us, offered no hairs as exhibit.
They offered no hairs as part of their case.
Now, the Attorney General in response to all of these about the hair offers two points.
One point is a formal one that no request was made by the accused counsel of -- for the evidence we claim was suppressed.

This, we are submitting to Your Honors, that the Brady against Maryland cannot be read as requiring such a request and we have cited the case, U.S. versus Wilkins decided by Judge Thurgood Marshall which reviews all the authorities on this.
Incidentally, this point was very similar to the point that bothered the Court before the Jencks case.

It was very much the same point that a report was available to contradict and the question was raised and the point was made in Mr. Justice Brennan's opinion in the Jencks case that how could anyone be expected to know the contents of report they hadn't seen.
The other point that the Attorney General makes is that the accused himself somehow knew because of this colloquy that took place during the 52-hour detention period.

Note, the Attorney General is in the awkward position of claiming that the accused -- a statement they made to the accused that hairs matched is to be treated as fulfillment of their obligation under the Constitution to disclose that the hairs did not match.
Now, there was no disclosure at all that the hair within the child's vagina didn't match the accused hair.
There was simply some general garble conversation during this long detention period about hairs.
How old is he now?
He's been in the death house ten years.
He's approximately 30 years of age at the time of his conviction.
He's 40 years here of age.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: What you're saying is that whatever the hairs were that he saw during was 52 hours, were never identified by the prosecution as one of them being a hair from the child.
Never so identified, Mr. Justice Brennan, that's just what I'm saying yes sir.
Now, an electrocution for this man was averted six hours before it was to occur only as a result of the intervention of the United States District Court in the habeas corpus case.
The District Court reached the correct result perhaps for wrong reasons.
The Court of Appeals reached the wrong result for clearly wrong reasons.
And we ask this Court to reach the right result for the right reason.
I thank you.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. Michael.
Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.

The contentions of the petitioner in this case can be basically summarized into two broad categories, one, the lack of access to certain information, and secondly, the validity of the admission of his confession at the trial.
Concerning first, the issue of the defense's access to information perhaps their most significant issue is that of the finding of the hair.
Now, with respect to this issue, it is important to first determine what was revealed and what was not revealed.
At the District Court, when the petitioner testified, he testified that when in those same proceedings he had heard the state's attorney testify as to the result of this examination.
This was the first he had ever heard about that hair.
However, this conclusion is cast into doubt by his testimony at the trial itself.

Now, I'm talking about the chambers testimony that he gave when the question of his -- the admissibility of his confession first arose for the determination by the Court before it was submitted to the jury.
At that time, he testified that in effect he testified, “They took some pubic hairs from me.
They told me that another hair that it matched with.
I demand to look in the comparative microscope.
I looked, and I said those hairs don't match.
I'm just using the exact language with --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Who said that now?
This was the petitioner, Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: The defendant?
The defendant at the trial, yes Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Did that happen in the stated -- did that happen during the 52 hour detention?
It -- he testified to it, Your Honor.
As far as I know it is un-contradicted testimony in the record.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: So we can take that as true, that's what happened?
I think that that is a fair statement on the basis of this record Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And did he also say that, might be, they said that, in the record, state officials told him during that period that they had hairs which proved his guilt as to that effect?
I'll give you the exact language, Your Honor.
Try Volume 4, the Court will refer to this as the brown record, Volume 4, page 91 in 273 and 95.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: What page again did you say Mr. --?
What page did you say again?
First we'll start, Your Honor with page 90.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: 90, thank you.
At that point, he testified, about the middle of the second paragraph on page -- first full paragraph on page 90.
Also, they took a small quantity of hair from around my privates.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: This was testimony outside of the presence of the jury.
Yes it was, Your Honor.
This was on the admissibility of the confession.
At page 95 then Your Honors, I refer you next to that, the first full paragraph on page 95.

He says, “I was in this little room at all times in the evening of November 30, except for one time when I demanded to look through the microscope my own self, because they said these hairs belong to me.
Mr. Lich made a statement to me that certain hairs belonged to me.
He showed me some hairs there.
I demanded to go back and he took me there back into the laboratory and a small room which appeared to be a microscope room.
And I looked down and I said them hairs don't match.
I said them hairs don't belong to me.
And the chemist just looked at me and smiled.”

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Now, that was a couple of days after his arrest, was it not?
I'm not positive whether this -- yes on November 30, he was arrested on the 28, I believe, this was the 30th.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And he's arrested on the 28th and on the 30th according to his testimony anyway, he was confronted with these hairs.
Yes, Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: What's the date of the confession?
The confession is the 30th, Your Honor, the same day in which he was confronted with these hairs.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Now, did you say another page?
I thought I did, Your Honor, I was looking for it and I don't --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: The 273?
273, well that's just a repetition of the first statement, Your Honor.
This is at his testimony, this narrows his testimony, I believe, before the jury.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: For the jury?
This is his testimony before the jury at 273.
All he testified here Your Honor is he said, “Then they took a bunch of hairs from around my privates.”

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Did he tell the jury that?
Apparently so, Your Honor.
I'm trying to -- yes, this was before the jury.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: So he testified before the jury about the hair, did he not?
He testified only, Your Honor, that they took some hair from him.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Not that they showed him any as noted.
No, no Your Honor, not as he did before the -- and before the Court in private when he testified that they had showed him this hair.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Did he testify before the jury on -- just on the confession in which your Illinois procedure.
Was that sworn testimony?
Before the jury, no Your Honor, or before in the --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Before the jury.
Before the jury, it was sworn testimony.
Yes, Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Sworn testimony.
Sure.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Was he cross-examined on that testimony?
He was cross-examined, but I don't believe about that -- the point that we're talking about, Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: In other words, was counsel correct when he said that the state made no mention about the -- of the hairs in the whole file?
That is my understanding of the record, yes Your Honor.
Now --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, was that because the state decided it was not his hair?
Do you know why?
All I can do is make an inference from the record, Your Honor.
My inference from the record is that they did have this report showing that it was not his hair, and therefore never raised that issue at trial.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But they did raise it at trial.
You concede now that he has -- that we have to take it if they did tell him these hairs were his when at the time they were interrogating him before he signed his confession.
Although they knew then that at least the one that was found on the child's vagina was not his, that --
No, no I beg to differ with you on that Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, what is the fact?
The fact is that this interrogation as we said came back the 30th.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes.
It was taken place in November 30th.
They did not get the report, the scientific report as to the result of the comparison of these hairs until December 15, I believe it was.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Why did they tell him that they did match?
I do not know, Your Honor.
Perhaps the person who looked in the comparison microscope thought they did, but the record is -- has no information to guide us along those lines Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: What's the states view on the significance on the fact that on December 15, the state learned that these hairs did not match.
And that the state apparently concedes that the hair found on the smear came from the girl.
Well, I think that that is an inference that the prosecution made at the -- made and I think that I would've done this if I were to try to contradict that it as --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: That means your brief, as I read your brief, you concede the hair came from the vagina of the girl.
Certainly, it was found on a Kleenex that it had been used to take a vaginal smear.
I think that it is perfectly fair to make the assumption that that came from the vagina of the girl.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And do you agree that it was a pubic hair?
No I do not Your Honor.
The report of the chemist merely identified that was hair of human origin.
That is as far as we know.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But it's -- let's assume the defense had information that a hair was found in the vagina of the little girl and that it didn't match the pubic hair of the defendant.
I would suppose the defense would've put that testimony on before the jury, wouldn't it?
I'm not quite sure that I followed your question, Mr. Justice White.
Would you repeat it again, please?

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, I just wonder if the information the state had on December 15th from that report was of great interest for the defense.
That they should have revealed it.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes.
Well, of course we --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well I don't -- unless we break that in two parts, let's forget about should've revealed from then.
If you were defending and had that kind of information, would you introduce it to the trial?
I would think as the prosecution, Your Honor, that certainly if I had this sort of information that I would not introduce into my case in chief, no.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: No, but if you were defending.
Oh, if were defending, yes I would, Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But do you suppose it would've affected the outcome of that trial?

If the defense has had evidence that there has been found in the child a hair and that it was not the hair of the accused, if that evidence has been before the jury, do you suppose it might have affected the outcome of the term?
We are of course, Your Honor, dealing in a realm of supposition here.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I know, but that --
I would --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- the test and on a few is whether it would affect the outcome of the trial, isn't it?
I would submit --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: It might affect the outcome of the trial.

I would submit, Your Honor, that when we had before the jury, his own confession, a admission that he made to Betty Baldwin, and we have the profession of prior admission of guilt, the fact of a hair in the vagina which did not match his, I submit to you, would not have changed the result before that jury.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, what's the -- how typical do that in this case -- differently in the case?

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. Michael, as I understand it, you do not now represent to this Court that the hair which was found in the vaginal smear was not pubic hair.
You don't make that representation --
I make the --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- to concede the contrary.
I make the representation Your Honor that the record shows that it was a hair of human origin.
That it does not show that it was pubic hair.
It does not show that it was not a pubic hair.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And you do not here contend that it was not pubic hair?
I do contend that it was not shown to be a pubic hair, Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I understand you.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I wonder if this is impertinent.

When on the motion to suppress the confession made out of the presence of the jury, when the defendant told the Court that while he was in jail they had shown him -- they had told him first that his pubic hairs matched with those found in the girl, and that he been looked at the microscope and -- himself and then said, “Those are not -- those don't match.
They're not my hairs.”
And the state had this report from its own laboratory to the effect that they did not match.
Do you not think there was an obligation on the state to disclose the fact that it did have such a report and that it was consistent with what the defendant said?
Your Honor, I submit that on the basis of this record, the duty to disclose is not present for three reasons.
First, I submit that in effect, we can look at it that there was really no nondisclosure at all.

He was told, according to the petitioner's testimony that a hair was found in the vagina of the victim that it matched his -- I beg your pardon that his were taken for comparison purposes and a comparison was going to be made.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: No, I understand that he testified that they said that they did match his and that there's no denial on that on the part of the state.
There was a denial by the petitioner, Your Honor.
He was allowed to look into the microscope and said those hairs don't match.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes, but the state had already told him that they did match and he says that they didn't.
Does it say they didn't?

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And by the time the hearing came on, on the motion to suppress the state had a record from its laboratory to the effect that they did not match.

Now, do you not think that those are burden on the -- on the state to admit to the Court that that was a fact rather than leave it to the Court to believe that what they had told him about the matching was true and that what he said about the not matching was not true?
I believe there is some burden here Your Honor upon the prosecution -- upon the defense.
This statement was made in the -- the statement was made, the question could've been asked by the defense.
The defense could've made a motion for -- the defense knew Your Honor that there was a hair found in the vagina of the victim.
They knew that his were being taken for comparison purposes.

They never -- they had enough information Your Honor in closing argument and nothing else had been done to make -- to argue in closing argument to say, “Ladies and gentlemen of the jury, the state knew that there was hair found in the vagina of the victim.”

The state took, mere comparison with the defendant's and they never introduced that at trial, except the information was totally in the hands of the defense, the inference can be drawn that that -- I beg your pardon Your Honor, the prosecution.
The inference can be drawn that that hair was -- that that evidence was unfavorable.
They had that amount of information in their possession, Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. Michael, may I ask you questions?

Suppose that the report, I'm trying to get the state's position now, suppose at the written report in the hands of the state were to the effect that the -- in the smear, there was found a hair, that is a pubic hair, you think that it was found in the little girl, and that the pubic hair that was found there did not match the pubic hair of the defendant.
Let's suppose in other words that these were -- this sort of overwhelmingly exonerating report.
In your -- in the state's position, would the state be obligated to disclose that to the defense?
I think perhaps from my point of view that may be close to the knob of our problem.

Your Honor, we of course start with the -- with your proposition with Brady versus Maryland holds that evidence favorable to an accused relevant material to the evidence of either guilt or punishment in the hands of the -- on request, must be revealed.
We start with that as our basic proposition.
So then we ask on applying that proposition to the facts of the -- if I may, to the facts of this case first.
We submit that first there was really no nondisclosure.
We submit that he knew the hair was found in the vagina of the victim.
We knew that his were being taken for comparison purposes.
We know that he stated on the record that those hairs did not match him that that was never denied.
As thus interpreted, he knew the hair was found.
He knew what comparison was made.

He knew that they didn't matched, if we can put any credence in his own ability to compare, and I don't know enough about the hair examination to know that if a layman looks in that he can see whether it's obvious that hairs match or do not match.
But nevertheless, he admittedly denied it, immediately upon looking on it, immediately denied it and that denial was never denied.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I know but maybe there are some limits to looking upon a capital case which the state demands a man's life and there are some limits to looking upon it as solely upon test of wits and abilities.
And that's why I'm asking you what state's position is on the assumption that I stated.That is say let's suppose if this were --
If a proper --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- regular court where totally exonerating and let's suppose that the defense, because of negligence or stupidity or whatever, did not demand the production of the report or because they didn't know of its existence, which I take it, is a fact here, did not demand the production of it.
Do you think that the state would be justified as a constitutional matter in not volunteering that information?
I would assume, Your Honor that if one, you can see the materiality of this testimony.
Now, I must add in answering this question that both the District Court and the Court of Appeals based their decision on this point upon, the question of materiality of the evidence.
The District Court stated the hair found in the vagina of the victim was of not consequence and did not prejudice the petitioner's case.

The Court of Appeals stated, there is absolutely no evidence in the record to show that that hair was in the vagina was of the perpetrator of the crime, and they further held that on the basis of the damaged condition of the body, it could've been deposited by anybody who had examined the body or anybody who had handled the body since the crime.
That was the conclusion of the Court of Appeals, Your Honor.

So, but if we assume the materiality of the evidence, if we assume a proper request was made as envisioned by Brady versus Maryland, I then ask you that that information would have to be divulged, yes sir.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: That of course is not my question, but that's alright, go ahead now.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Do you have that pubic hair now or that hair?
I do not believe that it is amongst the exhibits now.
Maybe you know that it is not presently amongst the exhibit.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: It's not in existence?
If it is in existence, I do not know where it is, Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Did the doctor who made the report record whether it was a pubic hair or not a pubic hair?
No he did not, Your Honor.
I don't -- I beg your pardon, there was no doctor's report on that, Your Honor.
There was a chemist report.
The chemist did not -- only reported that it was hair of human origin, probably of human origin.
He uses this --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Did not report whether it was pubic hair.
They did not, Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Was there any testimony about whether there could've been any hair there from her own body at her age?
I'm not sure whether there was or not, Your Honor.
I believe there was not, but I just am not sure of that.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But you have no way of knowing now whether it was a pubic hair or not?
No, Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: No way to prove it one way or the other.
No, Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I was just wondering certainly that would not make any difference to us here for our observation but certainly the state must have that vial if that was in, wouldn't they, at this time while the case is still pending?
They had it on the habeas corpus proceeding, certainly they must have it now.
They wouldn't --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: They did --

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- have destroyed it, would they?

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Your Honor, I beg to differ with you, I do not think they had it at the habeas corpus proceeding.
If they had it, it would now be on the record.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Oh!
Pardon me, I understood that from the counsel that it was there.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: No, it was not, Your Honor.
The reason that it was not, I assume, it's because was never introduced into evidence at the trial.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I see.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: So there was -- it was not given that significance.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I just misunderstood what counsel said.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: We turn then to the aspect of Brady versus Maryland that requires a -- Brady versus Maryland says that nondisclosure upon request constitutes a violation of due process.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But you don't think it's significant within Brady and Maryland there was in fact a request?

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Your Honor, in the light of this case --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: No, but please answer the question.
I beg your pardon, excuse me.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: You do or don't consider it significant that there was in Brady and Maryland in fact they request?
Yes, Your Honor, I consider that that's significant.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Alright.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: What do you have to say about the request that we made in this case for an opportunity to examine the evidence?

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I submit Your Honor that it was too broad to meet the requirements of Brady versus Maryland.
All it said in the request itself Your Honor is found at page 2 of the Volume 4 of the record.

Now, comes the defendant, Lloyd Eldon Miller, by William Malmgren, his attorney, hereby moves the Court to make an order permitting the defendant to make, or cause to be made, upon such terms and conditions as the Court may seem necessary to adequately insure the interests of the parties, a scientific examination of the physical evidence to be introduced by the people in this cause, etcetera.

Now, even under Rule 16 of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure, Your Honor, in order to make a -- for the defendant to make a motion to examine physical evidence in the hands of the government, it is necessary that they show the materiality and the reasonableness.
I submit to Your Honors that this motion would not be -- would be held as improper under Rule 16 of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: What they're asking here was for the physical evidence that it is going to be introduced by the people in this cause.
And presumably that means that will give the state latitude to say, “Alright, we're going to have to use this, this and this and you can get it and make physical examination of it.”
So what's the deficiency under Rule 16 or otherwise?
I don't think that they have shown either the materiality or the reasonableness, Your Honor.
Now, one thing that is to be noted with respect to that motion is that they ask for the evidence that the state is going to introduce.
The hair wasn't even introduced as very technically interpreted.
The motion does not even apply to the hair.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I understand that, but it does apply to this part of the case involving the shorts.
Yes, Your Honor, it does.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And how at this particular time would the defense have known what the prosecution was going to introduce by way of physical evidence?
I assume that they -- the only way I can answer that question Your Honor is that they were given the right to view all the physical evidence in the case.
He made that motion.
They were allowed to go in.
They were allowed to view all the physical evidence in the case.
Now, they could've based -- the hair was seen of record that they saw the hairs when they made that view.
A motion -- in addition of the fact, that the defense knew that the hair was found in the vagina of the victim, knew that hair of petitioner was taken for comparison purposes.
I do not submit that it is too great a burden on the prosecution -- on the defense.
I beg your pardon, to make a motion for their result of that examination.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Did you say Mr. Michael that among the things they did see was the actual hair taken from the shorts?
The testimony, Your Honors, states that amongst the physical evidence seen was hair and hairs.
It does not define determining further, yes.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: That would identify them as including that the hair was --
Correct, Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, hair was in the vial, wasn't it?
The testimony does not state how it was, Your Honor.
All it states is that “What evidence did you see when you examined it?”
